lines.text: I bet I know a lot of things you don't know. I know that's not French you're singing.
That's right. About ten million people know it Portuguese.
I bet you can't speak French.
Right now, I sorry I speak *English*.
Elliot, I'm going to be a father again.
Good Heavens, Mr. Cheyne.
No, no no Elliot... just that it seems that smart little boys from so-called wealthy well-bred parents don't grow up very successfully by themselves.
15 years I've been fisherman, first time I catch fish like you.
[blows conch shell, and heads towards boat ringing bell]
HEY, Aboard the vessel!
Hey!
I bring you new kind of fish.
What'chu get?
I got new kind of fish. He got no tail. He got pants on his dorsal fin. I think maybe he about 10 year old.
[pulls up next to schooner and start hauling up boy]
Aw, its a kid ain't it?
Oh, Long Jack, what are you worry about? He admit the whole thing, like regular grown fella. He say he sorry. Everything all right now.
Nothing's all right till I beat his ears off! Get outta my way.
You touch that kid, I tear you apart, see! Manuel talking, I tear you apart, see! So don't get me mad, Long Jack. I get all crazy and sick inside.
Manuel?
It's okay, he do some work.
I did not. - That was work.
You clean something off deck, no?
You made me do something.
That was work.
Wake up, Little Fish. Hey, wake up, wake up! Somebody think you dead, they have celebrations.

I gonna get nifty suit. You know, purple colored. Oh, very nifty suit, with shoes to match and big pearl buttons. Oh, and then I get new tie with big yellow flowers. Oh, then I walk up and down Duckett Street, and I say "Hey, girls, girls. Hey, look, look. Manuel is in town."
Girls?
Oh sure, beautiful girls. I get maybe five, six girls in Gloucester. I tell each one I like her best. You gotta tell big lies to girls to make them happy.

[Imitating the fog horn of a passing Ocean Liner]
O-o-o-o-o! O-o-o-o-o! You try run Manuel down, huh? You big killer whale smokestack. You try swallow Manuel - like he little smelt, huh? O-o-o-o-o! O-o-o-o-o! That's all you ever gonna say. O-o O-o-o!
What smells so bad?
Smells? Ain't nothin' smells bad around here. Oh, you means de fish. But they ain't got no smell. Dems nice clean salt fish.
You sure is a tonic to yourself.
Wait till you see some of the places we go.
What places?
Oh, Stone Fence, St. Pierre's Bank, Whale Deep, Virgin Rock. Pop gets a ride along with the fish. Folks say he thinks like a codfish.
Well, if thinking like a codfish is going to get me where I want to get, I don't care how he thinks.
Look, Long Jack. He's got such few fish, they die of loneliness, I think!
You did better maybe?
Aww, wait you see what I get. I get fish with hair on him!
Aw, there my new kind of fish. How you feel, little fish?
Hey! I do more work as you do with your best girl six brothers!

[SInging]
Yea-ho, little fish, don't cry, don't cry. Yea-ho, little fish, don't cry, don't cry. Once Doc makes a biscuit and throw them away, next day no more fish come around boat to play. Yea-ho, little fish, don't cry, don't cry. Yea-ho, little fish, don't cry, don't cry. Said cabbage to fish cake who lay on one dish, I beautiful cabbage you only poor fish. Yea-ho, little fish, don't cry, don't cry. Yea-ho, little fish, don't cry, don't cry...
The food was awful. But, it was better than nothing, I guess.
All cleared up, hasn't it? The weather - its nice now.
It was till you come up.
Well, they sent me up.

[Sarcastically]
No. No, I bet they ask you stay.

I guess you don't know nothing, huh? Sailor's angel he fly around up there all time. You watch here, look out for 25 men below. He watch, up there, he look out for you. You go asleep, maybe. He tap you on shoulder with his wing and he say, "Hey, Manuel, wake up, I ashamed for you." He very nice fella. Everybody know that.
Why do you keep singing for?
Because I like to sing.
I never heard that song before.
Me neither. I just make 'em up.
You can't write songs.
I don't write 'em. I just find 'em in my mouth.
A song can't be any good like that! When you just make it up.
Say, that's best kind songs. When you feel good inside, like-like trade winds, she just come out.
[singing]
O my beautiful lady...
People learn songs. Songs aren't just inside of people like that.
Say, sometimes a song so big and sweet inside, I-I I just can't get 'em out. And then I look up at stars and maybe cry, it feels so good. Don't you never feel like this? No, I guess you don't.
My father, when he alive, he made better songs than me!
What kind of songs did he sing?
Songs about the sun and the sea. Songs about the clouds. Big songs - about the wind and the storms. And little songs too - about the tip on my mother's nose. Oh, my father, he feel beautiful inside.
My father was the best fisherman on the whole Madeira islands! And that's everyplace.
Well, that's not so much.
How you mean not so much?
Well, I mean he didn't do much for you. I mean, he didn't leave you anything.

He didn't leave - ? He-he leave me this hurdy-gurdy that his grandfather leave him! He teach me how to fish, how to sail boat! He give me arms and hands and feet, feeling good outside and he teach me how to feel good inside! My father do all this and he have 17 other kids beside - what else a father do?
You're trailing me because I can find cod where you can't find half a pound of sick squid.
He beat us into Gloucester this trip, too, I think.

Oh, you think so, do ya? Well, now listen to me, I'm gonna tell you something. I ain't so dumb! Fussin' around like that will make him think the fishin' is good here. Then, in the mornin', when the fog banks roll in, we'll sneak out and leave him sittin' here. Baitin' big and catchin' small, while we're out findin' fish! We'll have a full hole and be tied up in Gloucester by the first of August and he'll still be out here, flounderin' around, tryin' to catch fish or I'll look more like a halibut than he did.

[singing]
There's a place in my heart for the one I love best, And I still have her picture tattooed on my chest. Yea-ho, little fish, don't cry, don't cry. Yea-ho, little fish, don't cry, don't cry...
Go away with your foolish questions which don't have no brain!

[singing]
Bingo, Bingo, came to woo her, brought a lot of presents to her, O what a terrible man, O what a terrible man...
You fish for sperm whale maybe?
He-he.
Don't laugh. Beside, you laugh no good. He-he-he-he. Like seagull.
I guess I want to do something.

Yes, but you want to do just what you want to do! I tell you what you do, you go below in galley and help Doc. You carry slops. You sweat in galley like Dan did, before you talk about being fisherman. Go on, now, go on.
You think Manuel soft with that kid, huh? You think cause I catch him I let him still be Jonah, huh?
I suppose you deny I showed you the road to this spot a year ago this very day! Ya cross-eyed mackerel!
Pop could find fish in a graveyard!
It might go faster if our Jonah-catcher would throw away his hand-line and bend on a troll for once.
You no think I catch as much as fish as you, huh, Jack?
I ain't sayin' that.
Maybe you just bump your head on bunk when you get up this morning, huh?
Or, maybe you Portuguese just don't know nothin' about troll fishing.
I tell you what I do, I take Jonah-kid with me tomorrow. I fish hand-line, I show him same time. I bet you we bring in fish as you and Nate together.
more fish as me and Nate together.
More fish *than* you and Nate together.
[Crew laughs]
Now, come on. 1-2-3 Row! Row! We get some place. Bottom of the ocean, I think, frankly.

Now we fish. - Well, go on, bait your hook. How you think he gonna fish, sitting there looking at me! - Naw, you bait just like you row boat. Here. Look. You must put barb all way through. Like this. Otherwise, that fish he spit that out six seven times when he feels something. You know, this fish he don't go to school. He don't know French; but, he pretty smart too. Now, drop him down to bottom. Then pull up - 'bout six inches, maybe, so he can fish straight in eye and say, "Look here, I got corn beef and cabbage."
Here, I've got one!
[Pulls up his line, but no fish]
You got new idea, maybe, too, huh? What you think? We just feed fish, free, here, for nothing?
I-I guess I was too anxious, again.
I told you, stay away from that anxious business. Let the fish be anxious. Here. Look. One - Two - Now it's in his mouth - Now, up he come.
Gosh, can I take him off the hook?
We got not time for that. We don't know these fish personal.
Gee, I've got one now!
All right, pull 'em up! Pull 'em up! Don't let him stay down there and tell all other fish what is going on. Pull 'em up!
[Harvey almost falls out of the boat]
Hey, wait a minute, Hey. You gonna bring fish up see you? You going down see him? Pull 'em up!
Nothing going on, here, now. That fish he have meeting down below. He tell all other fish there's something not so funny going on.
Oh, oh, I'm sorry.
What you sorry about?
Well, I mean, your father, they didn't find him.
What they need find him for? He all right.
Well, but, drowning out in the ocean, all alone at night.
What's the trouble about that? That fine way. The savior, he take my father up to fishermen's heaven - with all his old friends.

Savior, he see my father all tired and wet down there in the water. So, he light the harbor buoy and he say, "Come on up, old Manuel. I so happy you come up here to help us." And my father, he say, "Thank you. I am very happy to come up, too. Maybe I show you something about fishing up here, huh?" And then they all laugh. And the Savior he put his arm around my father and he give him brand new dory to fish in.
Do you think they really fish in heaven?
Well, sure they fish in heaven. What else they do?

The Apostles, they all fishermen, ain't they? Remember that Simon called Peter? Remember that time when he don't catch no fish in the Sea of Galilee? And the Savior, he stand on the shore and he say, "Simon, you throw your net on the right side." Simon, he throw his net on the right side and he catch so many fish his net almost break in two. Oh, I think the Savior, he the best fish man. But, my father, he come next.
Hey, sleepyface! Look! You log on the bunk.
Oh, say, I didn't...
Easy now, easy, he's a big one. And stay off your backside, you hear me. Come on, pull 'em up!
I'm try-trying to...
Oh, you want Manuel's help, huh? I think you get blisters. Blisters good for fisherman. Come on, pull 'em up! Pull 'em up!
By golly, my little fish catch fish bigger than he is.
Manuel and his little fish, they beat everybody. We make fisherman out of you, huh, little fish?
What happens - what do you do when people don't speak to you, around here?

You have to settle that yourself, son. I'm skipper to a crew; but, I ain't dry nursemaid. And I don't take no part in squabbles. They settle that between themselves, just like everything else. Whatever's foul between between you and Manuel, you'll have to free and clear yourselves.
I think you put hooks in yourself, so you got chance to drink more rum, huh?
What's the matter, little fish? You sleepy?
I-I'm so ashamed, Manuel.
Sure. We all got to be ashamed once. So we don't do things again when we got be ashamed of, see?

[singing]
There's a school of fish when I leap in the sea. Where the little fish study geography.
[Talking]
My father, he teach this song and I put your kind of words to it.
[singing]
Now they write on the slate and they read from a book. Learn to run with the bait and just leave 'em the hook.
[Talking]
I gotta sing every time I get mad. It drive those flying fish out of my stomach, you know?
[singing]
Yea-ho little fish, don't cry, don't cry. You'll be a balaya by and by.
[Talking]
Balaya - that mean *big* fish, like whale, you know?
[singing]
With your fins and a tail to help you sail. And maybe some wings to help you fly. Yea-ho little fish, don't cry, don't cry. Yea-ho little fish, don't cry, don't cry...
Walt Cushman beats me into Gloucester? I'll hang myself with an eel.
Why, I know this bottom as well as my wife knows her own kitchen.
I think maybe I light candle for myself, too. I had a few bad thoughts this trip.
You never had any bad thoughts.
Oh, sure.
What were they?
Oh, I forget 'em now; but, I had them, I think.
We have good times together, say little fish. We laugh. We sing. So, you smile, now. So, smile.
But, there's no fishing out there, is there?
The best trout fishing in the world! And if I do say it myself, I can teach you to cast a fly wherever you want to put one.
I read about that kind of fishing, once, in a magazine. Manuel said that any fish that ate a bug was some kind of a frog.
